sections.content-first: Cuisines of Arunachal Pradesh are a tantalizing journey through the diverse landscapes and rich cultural tapestry of this enchanting Indian state. Each dish is like a storyteller, weaving tales of traditions, rituals, and the deep bond between the indigenous communities and their land. The flavors are a fusion of nature's bounty, incorporating wild herbs, aromatic spices, and indigenous ingredients that celebrate the harmony between humans and their environment. From fragrant thukpas that warm the soul on misty mountain mornings to smoked meats that evoke the spirit of tribal gatherings around bonfires, Arunachal's cuisine is a testament to the resourcefulness and culinary artistry of its people. The vibrant array of dishes reflects not only a connection with the land but also the bonds between communities, as food is often shared during festivals and ceremonies. Arunachal's cuisine is a reminder that food isn't just sustenance, but a cultural heritage to be savored, shared, and celebrated, bringing people together in the embrace of flavors that have stood the test of time.
sections.title: Arunachal Pradesh
sections.content-second: Wungwut Ngam is a traditional dish of Arunachal Pradesh. It is a type of smoked pork curry that is cooked with bamboo shoot, ginger, garlic, green chilies, and local herbs. The dish has a smoky and spicy flavor that is enhanced by the sourness of the bamboo shoot and the freshness of the herbs.
sections.content-second-ptII: To prepare this dish, the pork is cut into pieces and smoked over fire for several hours. The smoked pork is then boiled with water, salt, and turmeric until tender. The bamboo shoot is sliced and soaked in water to remove the bitterness. The ginger, garlic, and green chilies are crushed into a paste. The paste is then fried in oil and added to the pork along with the bamboo shoot and the herbs. The dish is simmered until the gravy thickens and the flavors blend well . Wungwut Ngam is served with steamed rice or millet and enjoyed with local beverages such as rice beer or apong . Wungwut Ngam is a delicacy that showcases the rich and diverse culinary heritage of Arunachal Pradesh.
sections.content-third: Pika Pila is a traditional dish of Arunachal Pradesh. It is a type of fermented fish pickle that is prepared with fresh river fish, mustard oil, salt, and spices. The dish has a tangy and spicy flavor that is enhanced by the fermentation process.
sections.content-third-ptII: To prepare this dish, the fish is cleaned and cut into small pieces. The fish pieces are then mixed with salt, turmeric, red chili powder, and mustard oil. The mixture is then transferred to a glass jar and sealed tightly. The jar is kept in a warm place for about a week or more, depending on the desired level of fermentation. The pickle is then ready to eat or store for later use . Pika Pila can be eaten as a snack or as a side dish with steamed rice or millet. It can also be enjoyed with local beverages such as rice beer or apong . Pika Pila is a delicacy that showcases the rich and diverse culinary heritage of Arunachal Pradesh.
sections.content-fourth: Chura Sabzi is a traditional dish of Arunachal Pradesh. It is a type of vegetable curry that is prepared with chura, which is a local variety of fern. The dish has a mild and earthy flavor that is enhanced by the use of ginger, garlic, green chilies, and local herbs.
sections.content-fourth-ptII: To prepare this dish, the chura is washed and chopped, and then boiled with water and salt until soft. The ginger, garlic, and green chilies are crushed into a paste. The paste is then fried in oil and added to the chura along with the herbs. The dish is simmered until the gravy thickens and the flavors blend well . Chura Sabzi is served with steamed rice or millet and enjoyed with local beverages such as rice beer or apong . Chura Sabzi is a delicacy that showcases the rich and diverse culinary heritage of Arunachal Pradesh.
sections.content-fifth: Ngatok is a traditional dish of Arunachal Pradesh, a state in northeastern India. It is a type of fish soup that is cooked with ginger, garlic, green chilies, and local herbs. The dish has a light and aromatic flavor that is enhanced by the use of bamboo tubes, which are used to boil the fish and the water. The bamboo tubes impart a smoky aroma to the soup and also keep the fish moist and tender.
sections.content-fifth-ptII: To prepare this dish, the fish is cleaned and cut into small pieces. The fish pieces are then mixed with salt, turmeric, red chili powder, and mustard oil. The mixture is then transferred to a glass jar and sealed tightly. The jar is kept in a warm place for about a week or more, depending on the desired level of fermentation. The pickle is then ready to eat or store for later use . Pika Pila can be eaten as a snack or as a side dish with steamed rice or millet. sections.content-sixth: Apong is a traditional beverage of Arunachal Pradesh, a state in northeastern India. It is a type of rice beer that is prepared by fermenting cooked rice with yeast and water. The yeast is obtained from the bark or leaves of certain plants, such as marcha, phut, or mepok. The fermentation process takes about a week or more, depending on the desired strength and flavor of the beer.
sections.content-sizth-ptII: Apong is usually consumed during festivals, celebrations, or social gatherings. Apong is served in bamboo mugs or bamboo tubes and enjoyed with local delicacies such as fish, pork, or vegetables. Apong has a mild and refreshing taste and can vary in color from white to brown . Apong is a beverage that showcases the rich and diverse culinary heritage of Arunachal Pradesh.

sections.content-first: Cuisines of Assam, much like the state itself, embody a blend of rich traditions and vibrant diversity. Every dish carries within it a piece of Assam's history, culture, and geography. The use of simple yet potent ingredients like rice, fish, and green leafy vegetables is a reflection of the region's agrarian roots and its close proximity to the mighty Brahmaputra River. The flavors are an intricate dance of sweet, savory, and spicy, with a harmonious incorporation of traditional herbs and spices that lend a distinct character to Assamese cuisine. Whether it's the comforting embrace of a bowl of 'aaloo pitika' or the aromatic allure of 'masor tenga', each bite carries the essence of Assam's familial warmth and hospitality. The art of fermentation is celebrated through the ubiquitous 'xôkôta,' a sour chutney that symbolizes the state's culinary ingenuity. Assamese cuisine isn't just about flavors; it's about a way of life that revolves around community, shared meals, and the cyclical rhythms of nature. The food speaks to the intimate relationship between the people and their land, echoing the sentiment that eating is an act of connection, a homage to the land and the ancestors. In every dish, from street-side snacks to elaborate feasts, Assam's soul is laid bare, waiting to be savored and embraced.
sections.title: Assam
sections.content-second: Haah Joha Kumura is a traditional Assamese dish that is made with duck meat and a special type of ash gourd called joha kumura. Joha kumura is a variety of ash gourd that has a fragrant aroma similar to joha rice, which is a type of aromatic rice grown in Assam. The dish is cooked with minimal spices such as ginger, garlic, green chilies, and black pepper to retain the natural flavor of the duck and the ash gourd.
sections.content-second-ptII: This dish is usually prepared during the winter season, as duck meat is considered to be warming and nutritious. It is also a part of the Uruka feast, which is a celebratory feast held on the eve of Magh Bihu, the harvest festival of Assam. The dish is served with steamed rice and accompanied by other delicacies such as pitika, khar, and tenga. Haah Joha Kumura is a delicacy that showcases the rich and diverse culinary heritage of Assam.
sections.content-third: Dhekia Xaak is a traditional dish of Assam that is made with fiddlehead ferns, which are the young and coiled fronds of a fern plant. The dish is also known as Dhekia Xaak Bhaji or stir-fried fiddlehead ferns. The fiddlehead ferns are locally called dhekia and belong to the matteuccia genus of ferns. They are harvested in the spring season and sold in the local markets wrapped in banana leaves.
sections.content-third-ptII: To prepare this dish, the tender parts of the dhekia are washed and chopped, and then stir-fried with potatoes, black chickpeas, onion, green chilies, turmeric, and mustard oil. The dish has a tangy and pungent taste due to the natural flavor of the dhekia and the raw mustard oil. It is a simple and healthy dish that is rich in potassium, iron, and manganese. Dhekia Xaak is served as a side dish with steamed rice and dal, or with other delicacies such as fish curry, khar, or tenga. Dhekia Xaak is a delicacy that showcases the rich and diverse culinary heritage of Assam.
sections.content-fourth: Lai Xaak Gahori is a traditional Assamese dish that is made with pork and mustard greens. It is a simple and healthy dish that is cooked with minimal spices and oil. The pork is either boiled or stir-fried with the greens, ginger, garlic, green chilies, and mustard oil. The dish has a tangy and pungent taste due to the natural flavor of the mustard greens and the raw mustard oil.
sections.content-fourth-ptII: This dish is usually prepared during the winter season, as pork is considered to be warming and nutritious. It is also a part of the Uruka feast, which is a celebratory feast held on the eve of Magh Bihu, the harvest festival of Assam. The dish is served with steamed rice and accompanied by other delicacies such as pitika, khar, or tenga. Lai Xaak Gahori is a delicacy that showcases the rich and diverse culinary heritage of Assam.
sections.content-fifth: Patot Diya Maas (Steamed Fish Wrapped in Banana Leaf) is a traditional Assamese dish that is made with fresh river fish and aromatic herbs. It is a simple and healthy dish that is cooked by steaming the fish wrapped in banana leaves or turmeric leaves. The fish is mixed with coriander, cilantro, onion, green chilies, salt, and mustard oil, which give it a tangy and pungent flavor. The banana leaves or turmeric leaves impart a fragrant aroma to the fish and also keep it moist and tender.
sections.content-fifth-ptII: This dish is usually prepared during the spring or summer season, when the fish and the leaves are easily available. It is also a part of the Uruka feast, which is a celebratory feast held on the eve of Magh Bihu, the harvest festival of Assam. The dish is served with steamed rice and accompanied by other delicacies such as pitika, khar, or tenga. Patot Diya Maas is a delicacy that showcases the rich and diverse culinary heritage of Assam.
sections.content-sixth: Pitha of Assam is a traditional dish that is made with rice flour, coconut, jaggery, sesame seeds, and other ingredients. It is a type of cake or dumpling that is either fried, roasted, or steamed. Pitha can be sweet or savory and can have various shapes and fillings. Pitha is usually prepared during the winter season or on festive occasions such as Bihu, the harvest festival of Assam. Some of the popular varieties of pitha are til pitha, narikol pitha, and ketli pitha. Til pitha is a sweet pitha that is made with rice flour and black sesame seeds. Narikol pitha is a sweet pitha that is made with rice flour and grated coconut. Ketli pitha is a savory pitha that is made with rice flour and onion.
sections.content-sixth-ptII: Doi Chira is another traditional dish of Assam that is made with flattened rice, yogurt, and jaggery. It is a simple and refreshing dish that is eaten as a breakfast or dessert. Doi Chira is prepared by soaking the flattened rice in water for some time and then draining it. The flattened rice is then mixed with yogurt, jaggery, banana, and dry fruits. Doi Chira has a creamy texture and a sweet-sour flavor . Doi Chira is also a part of the Uruka feast, which is a celebratory feast held on the eve of Magh Bihu, the harvest festival of Assam . Doi Chira is a delicacy that showcases the rich and diverse culinary heritage of Assam.

sections.content-first: Cuisine of Meghalaya is a celebration of the state's picturesque landscapes and the vibrant culture of its indigenous communities. Each dish tells a story of a region deeply connected to its natural surroundings, where mist-covered hills and lush valleys provide a backdrop for culinary traditions that have stood the test of time. The flavors are a harmonious blend of earthiness and zest, drawing from the local produce such as rice, pork, and a plethora of forest-grown herbs. Meghalaya's cuisine is an embodiment of resourcefulness, making use of the bounties offered by the land and transforming them into hearty, nourishing meals. From the fiery kick of 'jadoh' to the comfort of 'dohneiiong,' a dish made from fermented pork and black sesame seeds, the food mirrors the warmth and resilience of the Meghalayan people. In a world that's ever-changing, Meghalaya's culinary traditions stand as a testament to the importance of preserving cultural heritage and passing down recipes that connect generations. The cuisine doesn't just satiate hunger; it offers a taste of Meghalaya's soul, a chance to immerse oneself in the flavors of a land where tradition and nature coexist in perfect harmony.
sections.title: Meghalaya
sections.content-second: Jodoh is a traditional dish of Meghalaya. It is a type of rice and fish porridge that is cooked with ginger, garlic, onion, green chilies, and turmeric. The dish has a mild and soothing flavor that is enhanced by the use of local herbs such as mint or coriander. Jodoh is a simple and healthy dish that is rich in protein and carbohydrates.
sections.content-second-ptII: Jodoh is usually prepared with fresh river fish such as carp or catfish. The fish is cleaned and cut into pieces. The rice is washed and soaked in water for some time. The ginger, garlic, onion, and green chilies are chopped finely. The fish and the rice are then cooked together in a pot with water, salt, and turmeric until soft. The dish is then garnished with herbs and served hot or cold. Jodoh can be eaten as a main course or as a snack. It can also be enjoyed with local beverages such as rice beer or tea . Jodoh is a delicacy that showcases the rich and diverse culinary heritage of Meghalaya.
sections.content-third: Nakham Bitchi is a traditional dish of Meghalaya. It is a type of spicy fish soup that is prepared with dried fish, ginger, garlic, onion, green chilies, and black pepper. The dish has a strong and pungent flavor that is enhanced by the use of local herbs such as mint or bay leaves. Nakham Bitchi is a simple and aromatic dish that is rich in protein and vitamins.
sections.content-third-ptII: Nakham Bitchi is usually prepared with dried fish such as nakham or ngari, which are fermented fish products. The dried fish is soaked in water for some time and then boiled with water, salt, and turmeric until soft. The ginger, garlic, onion, green chilies, and black pepper are crushed into a paste. The paste is then fried in oil and added to the fish along with the herbs. The dish is simmered until the soup thickens and the flavors blend well . Nakham Bitchi is served hot with steamed rice or bread and enjoyed with local beverages such as rice beer or tea . Nakham Bitchi is a delicacy that showcases the rich and diverse culinary heritage of Meghalaya.
sections.content-fourth: Dohkhlieh is a traditional dish of Meghalaya. It is a type of pork salad that is prepared with boiled pork, onion, ginger, green chilies, and black pepper. The dish has a fresh and spicy flavor that is enhanced by the use of local herbs such as mint or coriander. Dohkhlieh is a simple and delicious dish that is rich in protein and iron.
sections.content-fourth-ptII: Dohkhlieh is usually prepared with pork head, which is considered to be a delicacy in Meghalaya. The pork head is cleaned and cut into pieces. The pork pieces are then boiled with water, salt, and turmeric until tender. The onion, ginger, green chilies, and black pepper are chopped finely. The pork and the onion mixture are then mixed together and seasoned with salt and lemon juice. The dish is then garnished with herbs and served cold or at room temperature. Dohkhlieh can be eaten as a main course or as a snack. It can also be enjoyed with local beverages such as rice beer or tea . Dohkhlieh is a delicacy that showcases the rich and diverse culinary heritage of Meghalaya.
sections.content-fifth: Pumaloi is a traditional dish of Meghalaya. It is a type of steamed rice cake that is prepared with powdered rice, water, and salt. The dish has a soft and fluffy texture and a mild flavor that can be enhanced by adding sugar, honey, or jaggery. Pumaloi is a simple and versatile dish that can be eaten as a breakfast, snack, or dessert.
sections.content-fifth-ptII: Pumaloi is usually prepared with red rice, which is a local variety of rice that has a nutty taste and a reddish color. The rice is washed and dried, and then ground into a fine powder. The powder is then mixed with water and salt to form a thick batter. The batter is then poured into small bamboo tubes or moulds and steamed over fire or boiling water. The rice cakes are then removed from the tubes or moulds and served hot or cold. Pumaloi can be enjoyed with local delicacies such as fish, pork, or vegetables. Pumaloi can also be enjoyed with local beverages such as rice beer or tea . Pumaloi is a delicacy that showcases the rich and diverse culinary heritage of Meghalaya.

sections.content-first: Cuisines of Nagaland are a mesmerizing fusion of ancient traditions and the wild beauty of its landscapes. The flavors are a symphony of contrasts, where fiery spices dance alongside the delicate aromas of herbs unique to the region. From the distinctive aroma of 'axone' to the adventurous allure of 'smoked pork with bamboo shoot', every meal is an invitation to explore the uncharted territories of taste. The cuisine mirrors the Naga society's close relationship with nature, where hunting and gathering have transcended into an art form. Sharing a meal in Nagaland is a sacred ritual, a gesture of hospitality that bridges gaps and nurtures bonds. The culinary journey through Nagaland is an exploration of the flavors that have endured generations, carrying with them the stories of ancestral roots and the vibrant spirit of a community deeply connected to its traditions.

The dish has a sour and spicy flavor that is enhanced by the use of fermented fish paste, which is locally called ngari. Akibeye is a simple and healthy dish that is rich in vitamin C and iron.
sections.content-third-ptII: Akibeye is usually prepared with fresh or dried colocasia leaves, which are locally called akhuni. sections.content-first: Cuisine of Manipur is a captivating journey into a land that seamlessly blends history, culture, and nature onto the plate. Each dish is a work of art, intricately woven with the threads of tradition and innovation. The flavors are a symphony of contrasts, where spicy and mild, tangy and sweet, come together to create a harmonious melody for the palate. Manipur's cuisine is a reflection of its diverse communities, each contributing their unique touch to the culinary tapestry. From the invigorating pungency of 'eromba' to the delightful simplicity of 'chingri', a dish made from water spinach, the food encapsulates the vibrant spirit of Manipur. The generous use of local ingredients, such as bamboo shoots, fish, and leafy greens, paints a picture of a society closely intertwined with its natural environment. Meals in Manipur are more than just sustenance; they are rituals of togetherness, often enjoyed as communal affairs that strengthen bonds and celebrate unity. The cuisine beckons you to explore the nuances of Manipur's history and its ongoing journey of self-discovery. It invites you to not just taste, but experience the essence of a land where every bite is a doorway to the heart and soul of its people.
sections.title: Manipur
sections.content-second: Chamthong or Kangshoi is a traditional dish of Manipur. It is a type of vegetable soup that is cooked with seasonal vegetables, fish, ginger, garlic, onion, green chilies, and local herbs. The dish has a light and refreshing flavor that is enhanced by the use of ngari, which is a fermented fish product. Chamthong or Kangshoi is a simple and healthy dish that is rich in vitamins and minerals.
sections.content-second-ptII: Chamthong or Kangshoi is usually prepared with fresh or dried fish such as carp or catfish. The fish is cleaned and cut into pieces. The vegetables such as cabbage, beans, carrot, potato, radish, or pumpkin are chopped into large pieces. The ginger, garlic, onion, green chilies, and herbs are chopped finely. The fish and the vegetables are then cooked together in a pot with water, salt, turmeric, and ngari until soft. The dish is then garnished with herbs and served hot with steamed rice or millet. Chamthong or Kangshoi can be eaten as a main course or as a snack. It can also be enjoyed with local beverages such as rice beer or zutho . Chamthong or Kangshoi is a delicacy that showcases the rich and diverse culinary heritage of Manipur.
sections.content-third: Singju is a traditional dish of Manipur. It is a type of salad that is prepared with various vegetables, herbs, and spices. The dish has a crunchy and spicy flavor that is enhanced by the use of roasted chickpea flour, which is locally called bora. Singju is a simple and refreshing dish that is rich in fiber and antioxidants.
sections.content-third-ptII: Singju can be prepared with different combinations of vegetables such as cabbage, lotus stem, banana flower, carrot, radish, or cucumber. The vegetables are washed and shredded or chopped finely. The herbs such as coriander, mint, or chameleon plant are also chopped finely. The spices such as ginger, garlic, green chilies, and ngari are crushed into a paste. The roasted chickpea flour is then mixed with water and salt to form a thick sauce. The sauce is then added to the vegetables and the herbs and tossed well. The dish is then garnished with roasted sesame seeds and served cold or at room temperature. Singju can be eaten as a main course or as a snack. It can also be enjoyed with local beverages such as rice beer or zutho . Singju is a delicacy that showcases the rich and diverse culinary heritage of Manipur.
sections.content-fourth: Chak-hao-Kheer is a traditional dish of Manipur. It is a type of rice pudding that is prepared with black rice, milk, sugar, and dry fruits. The dish has a creamy and sweet flavor that is enhanced by the natural color and aroma of the black rice. Chak-hao Kheer is a simple and delicious dish that is rich in antioxidants and iron.
sections.content-fourth-ptII: Chak-hao Kheer is usually prepared with chak-hao, which is a local variety of black rice that has a nutty taste and a deep purple color. The rice is washed and soaked in water for some time. The milk is boiled in a large pot and then the rice is added to it. The mixture is then cooked on low heat until the rice is soft and the milk is thickened. The sugar and the dry fruits such as raisins, cashews, or almonds are then added to the pudding and mixed well. The dish is then garnished with more dry fruits and served hot or cold. Chak-hao Kheer can be eaten as a dessert or as a snack. It can also be enjoyed with local beverages such as rice beer or zutho . Chak-hao Kheer is a delicacy that showcases the rich and diverse culinary heritage of Manipur.

The ginger, garlic, onion, green chilies, and herbs are chopped finely. The fermented sesame seeds are then fried in oil and added to the pork along with the bamboo shoot and the herbs. The dish is simmered until the gravy thickens and the flavors blend well . Mizo Vawksa is served with steamed rice or millet and enjoyed with local beverages such as rice beer or zutho . Mizo Vawksa is a delicacy that showcases the rich and diverse culinary heritage of Mizoram.
sections.content-fourth: Sanpiau is a traditional dish of Mizoram, a state in northeastern India. It is a type of rice porridge that is topped with fresh coriander, spring onion, crushed black pepper, and fish sauce. The dish has a savory and tangy flavor that is enhanced by the use of roasted rice powder, which is locally called zathuah. Sanpiau is a simple and refreshing dish that is rich in carbohydrates and vitamin C.
sections.content-fourth-ptII: Sanpiau is usually prepared with cooked rice, which is mashed and boiled with water and salt until thick. The rice porridge is then served in a bowl and sprinkled with roasted rice powder, which gives it a nutty taste and a crunchy texture. The dish is then garnished with fresh coriander, spring onion, crushed black pepper, and fish sauce, which give it a fresh and spicy taste. Sanpiau can be eaten as a breakfast, snack, or dessert. It can also be enjoyed with local beverages such as rice beer or zutho . Sanpiau is a delicacy that showcases the rich and diverse culinary heritage of Mizoram.
sections.content-fifth: Chhum Han is a traditional dish of Mizoram, a state in northeastern India. It is a type of steamed vegetable salad that is prepared with cabbage, beans, carrot, ginger, garlic, green chilies, and local herbs. The dish has a fresh and crunchy flavor that is enhanced by the use of vinegar, which is locally called saum. Chhum Han is a simple and refreshing dish that is rich in vitamin C and fiber.
sections.content-fifth-ptII: Chhum Han is usually prepared with fresh or boiled vegetables, depending on the preference and availability. The cabbage, beans, and carrot are chopped into small pieces. The ginger, garlic, green chilies, and herbs such as coriander or mint are chopped finely. The vegetables and the herbs are then mixed together and seasoned with salt and vinegar. The dish is then steamed in a bamboo steamer or a pot until the vegetables are soft and the vinegar is absorbed. The dish is then served cold or at room temperature. Chhum Han can be eaten as a main course or as a snack. It can also be enjoyed with local beverages such as rice beer or zutho . Chhum Han is a delicacy that showcases the rich and diverse culinary heritage of Mizoram.

sections.content-first: Cuisines of Tripura are a delightful exploration of a state nestled in the northeastern corner of India, where every dish is a blend of tradition, community, and a deep connection to the fertile land. The flavors are a reflection of Tripura's diverse cultural heritage, with influences from indigenous communities and neighboring regions. From the exquisite 'mui borok' to the comforting flavors of 'mui er aloo' and the aromatic allure of 'berma', each bite encapsulates the culinary wisdom passed down through generations. Tripura's cuisine mirrors the harmony between the people and nature, with ingredients like bamboo shoots, fish, and locally grown spices forming the heart of the dishes. Food is an integral part of the social fabric, bringing people together to celebrate festivals, mark significant events, and strengthen bonds. The cuisine is a reminder that history and culture can be experienced not just through monuments but through the senses. In every plate, you taste the stories of resilience, the love for heritage, and the celebration of life itself. Tripura's culinary offerings invite you to embrace the flavors, to savor the stories, and to join in the joyful journey of a state where food is more than nourishment; it's an expression of identity and community.
sections.title: Tripura
sections.content-second: Mui Borok is the name of the traditional cuisine of Tripura. Mui Borok is more than just food; it is a way of expressing the identity and pride of the people of Tripura, who have preserved their ancestral recipes and culinary practices for generations. Mui Borok reflects the cultural amalgamation and the natural bounty of the region, using indigenous ingredients and techniques that create unique flavors and textures.
sections.content-second-ptII: One of the main features of Mui Borok is the use of berma, a small, oil-pasted, and dry fermented fish that adds a salty and savory taste to many dishes. Berma is often combined with bamboo shoots, herbs, spices, and various kinds of fish and meat to create dishes that are cooked without oil and are considered healthy. Rice is the staple food in Tripura, and different varieties are used to make dishes like chakhwi, a rice dish infused with bamboo shoots, and mosdeng serma, a tangy tomato chutney. Fermentation is another important technique in Mui Borok cuisine, as it enhances the umami flavor and preserves the ingredients. Fermented bamboo shoots, fish, and soybean products are commonly used in Mui Borok dishes, giving them a tangy and pungent character.
sections.content-third: Chauk and Chuwarak are two types of alcoholic beverages that are prepared by the Tripuri people, the indigenous inhabitants of Tripura, a northeastern state in India. Chauk and Chuwarak are not only drinks, but also symbols of the Tripuri culture and identity, as they are used in various rituals, ceremonies, and festivals.
sections.content-third-ptII: Chauk is a rice beer that is fermented using a special yeast called thiat. Chauk is considered to be a prized drink among the Tripuris, and it is offered to the honored guests and the almighty Lord Garia, the deity of wealth and welfare. Chauk has a soothing taste and a distinctive aroma that attracts the drinkers. Chuwarak is a distilled liquor that is made from various ingredients such as rice, pineapple, jackfruit, or guria (a type of rice). Chuwarak is like scotch or champagne, and it has different grades and flavors depending on the quality and method of preparation. Chuwarak is said to be among the safest liquors in the world, as there has not been a single case of death due to poisoning by consumption.
sections.content-fourth: Kasoi Bwtwi is a popular dish from the cuisine of Tripura, a northeastern state in India. It is made with kosoi, a type of bean, and berma, a fermented fish paste that adds a salty and savory flavor to the dish. The beans are boiled and then cooked with onions, green chilies, garlic, and khundrupui leaves, which are a type of herb. The dish is seasoned with salt and turmeric and served with rice.
sections.content-fourth-ptII: Kasoi Bwtwi is a simple and healthy dish that showcases the use of local and organic ingredients in Tripura’s cuisine. The dish is oil-free and rich in protein and fiber. The berma gives the dish a distinctive aroma and taste that is characteristic of Tripuri food. The khundrupui leaves add a fresh and herbal touch to the dish
sections.content-fifth: Wahan Mosdeng is a traditional dish of Tripura, a northeastern state in India, that is made with pork, onion, coriander leaves, and green chili. The dish is cooked without oil and has a dry consistency. The pork is cut into small pieces and marinated with salt and turmeric. The onion, coriander leaves, and green chili are finely chopped and mixed together. The pork and the onion mixture are then cooked in a pan over low heat until the pork is tender and the water evaporates.
sections.content-fifth-ptII: Wahan Mosdeng is a delicious and lip-smacking dish that showcases the use of local spices and ingredients in Tripura’s cuisine. The dish has a spicy and savory flavor that comes from the green chili and the berma, a fermented fish paste that is added as a seasoning. The dish is also rich in protein and low in fat, as it does not use any oil or water. Wahan Mosdeng is enjoyed by meat lovers and is often served as a side dish with steamed rice or roti.

sections.content-first: Cuisines of Sikkim offer a tantalizing expedition through the Himalayan haven, where every bite is a portal to the region's rich cultural mosaic and breathtaking natural beauty. Sikkim's culinary landscape is a harmonious blend of local flavors and global influences, reflecting the state's history as a melting pot of cultures. From the sumptuousness of 'gyathuk' to the soul-warming embrace of sel roti', the dishes capture the essence of Sikkim's hospitality and reverence for nature. The cuisine is a tribute to the land's fertile soil and vibrant produce, as ingredients like buckwheat, ferns, and local herbs find their way onto plates, honoring the unique terroir. In Sikkim, food isn't just sustenance; it's a conduit for connection, a way to celebrate life's joys and navigate its challenges. Every meal carries a touch of the state's spirituality, echoing the tranquil monasteries and prayer flags that adorn its landscape. Sikkim's cuisine is a testament to adaptation, innovation, and a shared journey toward the future. With its array of flavors, Sikkim invites you to explore its mountains, rivers, and valleys not just with your eyes, but with every sense, as you savor the extraordinary tapestry of tastes that mirror the vibrant spirit of its people.
sections.title: Sikkim
sections.content-second: Jaanr is a traditional beverage of Sikkim, a northeastern state in India, that is made with fermented rice, millet, or barley. Jaanr is a type of rice beer that has a milky and cloudy appearance and a sweet and sour taste. Jaanr is prepared by soaking the grains in water and then adding a special yeast called marcha, which is made from rice flour and various herbs. The mixture is then stored in earthen pots or bamboo containers and allowed to ferment for a few days or weeks.
sections.content-second-ptII: Jaanr is a popular drink among the Sikkimese people, especially the Lepcha community, who are the original inhabitants of Sikkim. Jaanr is consumed on various occasions, such as festivals, weddings, rituals, and social gatherings. Jaanr is also offered to the gods and ancestors as a sign of respect and gratitude. Jaanr is usually served in bamboo mugs or wooden cups called tongba, and it is sipped through a bamboo straw called pipsing. Jaanr is a refreshing and intoxicating drink that can be enjoyed in any season.
sections.content-third: Phagshapa is a traditional dish of Sikkim, that is made with pork, radish, and dried red chilies. Phagshapa is a spicy and tangy dish that does not use any oil or water. The pork is cut into strips and cooked with the radish and the chilies in its own fat and juices. The dish is seasoned with salt and ginger and garnished with coriander leaves.
sections.content-third-ptII: Phagshapa is a popular dish among the Sikkimese people, especially the Bhutia community, who are fond of pork. Phagshapa is usually served with rice or dhindo, a thick porridge made from millet or buckwheat flour. Phagshapa is a hearty and satisfying dish that can be enjoyed in cold weather. Phagshapa is also considered to be a medicinal dish, as it is believed to cure colds and coughs.
sections.content-fourth: Thenthuk is a traditional dish of Sikkim, that is made with hand-pulled noodles, meat, and vegetables. Thenthuk is a type of thukpa, a noodle soup that originated in Tibet and is popular in the Himalayan regions. Thenthuk is different from other types of thukpa in that the noodles are not cut with a knife, but are torn by hand into irregular shapes. Thenthuk is a hearty and warming dish that can be enjoyed in any season.
sections.content-fourth-ptII: Thenthuk can be made with various kinds of meat, such as chicken, pork, beef, or mutton. The meat is boiled with water, salt, ginger, garlic, and spices to make a rich broth. The vegetables, such as cabbage, carrot, spinach, or radish, are added to the broth and cooked until tender. The noodles are made by kneading wheat flour with water and salt, and then pulling and stretching the dough into thin strands. The noodles are then added to the boiling broth and cooked for a few minutes. Thenthuk is served hot with chopped green onions and red chili sauce.
sections.content-fifth: Kinema Curry is a traditional dish of Sikkim, that is made with kinema, a fermented soybean product. Kinema is a protein-rich and flavorful food that is prepared by boiling soybeans, wrapping them in banana leaves, and fermenting them for a few days. Kinema has a soft and crumbly texture and a pungent and sour taste that is similar to cheese.
sections.content-fifth-ptII: Kinema Curry is a simple and delicious dish that showcases the use of fermentation and spices in Sikkim’s cuisine. The kinema is cooked with onion, garlic, ginger, tomato, turmeric, cumin, coriander, salt, and red chili powder to make a thick and aromatic curry. The curry is served with rice or roti and can be accompanied by other dishes such as gundruk (fermented leafy vegetables), sisnu (nettle soup), or phagshapa (pork with radish and chilies). Kinema Curry is a vegetarian dish that can be enjoyed by anyone who loves spicy and tangy food.
sections.content-sixth: Niguru With Churpi is a traditional dish of Sikkim, a northeastern state in India, that is made with niguru, a type of wild fern, and churpi, a soft cheese made from yak or cow milk. Niguru is a seasonal delicacy that grows in the forests and hills of Sikkim, and it is harvested by the local people. Niguru has a crunchy and bitter taste that contrasts with the creamy and mild taste of churpi.
sections.content-sixth-ptII: Niguru With Churpi is a simple and nutritious dish that showcases the use of local and organic ingredients in Sikkim’s cuisine. The niguru is washed and chopped into small pieces and then cooked with onion, garlic, ginger, tomato, salt, and red chili powder. The churpi is added at the end and melted into the niguru to make a thick and smooth gravy. The dish is served with rice or roti and can be enjoyed as a main course or a side dish. Niguru With Churpi is a vegetarian dish that can be enjoyed by anyone who loves green and leafy vegetables.
